title: A tenant died from Hiv what is the cost to have hazmat clean the room
question: The tenant said he would take care of having someone come out and clean the room. When family came to get his things they don't want to pay. Do I have any rights as a landlord. He never said anything about being sick when he moved in. I found out when he got sick and I had to call 911. He died in his room. I just found out he also had Hepatitis. What can I do?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Landlord or tenant,Month-to-month tenancy,Executor of will,Probate,Civil rights
answers:
The actual cost of cleanup portion of your question isn't a legal question, so you will have to determine the cost yourself. Presumably, you as the landlord could deduct such cost from the security deposit.

With respect to the issue of unpaid rent liability, the answer depends on whether the tenant had a lease or not. In California, when a tenant who has a tenancy for a specified term (such as a one-year lease) dies, tenancy continues until the end of the lease term, despite the tenant's death. Responsibility for the rest of the lease term passes to the tenant's executor or administrator. (Joost v. Castle (1939) 33 Cal.App.2d 138).

If the tenant had a month-to-month tenancy, the tenancy is terminated by written notice of the tenant's death. (Civil Code Section 1934.) The tenancy ends on the 30th day following the tenant's last payment of rent before the tenant's death. No 30-day or 60-day notice is required to terminate such tenancy. (Miller & Desatnik Management Co. v. Bullock (1990) 221 Cal.App.3d Supp. 13, 18-19).

Finally, note that you have statutory duties of disclosure under California law. If a prior occupant of the rental unit died in the unit within the last three (3) years, the owner or the owner's agent must disclose this fact to a prospective tenant when the tenant offers to rent or lease the unit. The owner or agent must disclose the manner of death, but is not required to disclose that the occupant was ill with, or died from, AIDS. However, the owner or agent cannot intentionally misrepresent the cause of death in response to a direct question. (See California Civil Code section 1710.2).

Is this a serious question? Who exactly would you expect to recover from?

Debts are not inherited or transferred to family members. I suppose if you could establish it as a legitimate debt you might sue his estate.

As to cleaning, there are professional cleaning outfits specializing in death scenes. Give one a call.
